9.06.text: Hi I'm Oli Spleen and I am originally from Hastings

12.48.text: which is an interesting & difficult place to grow up,

17.53.text: Since childhood I always felt closer to women than men

21.48.text: I remember from the first day

23.22.text: at primary school, I asked my mother

25.54.text: why am I not a girl?

26.66.text: because I didn't feel like I was able to

28.88.text: act in the way that the other boys did at school

33.12.text: I also would wear make up and women's clothes

36.16.text: from as young as I could remember, mostly at my grandma's house

41.16.text: and this is one of the earliest pictures of me.

45.94.text: I think my alter ego is called Jean Farnfield, at the time. She was a gardening presenter.

51.20.text: Men to me, at that age, seemed very disapproving authoritarian figures

55.64.text: When women, my mother, my sister, my grandmother and her friends

59.90.text: I was very close to them.

62.19.text: and they seemed warm and caring

64.43.text: and the thought of turning into a man

66.72.text: was something that horrified me at that age.

72.34.text: But in the same time I was made to feel that if I'd express myself in a feminine way

76.74.text: it would be seen at something very

81.84.text: Luckily I've lived into a time where gay and trans people  are a part of our social vocabulary

87.27.text: we have a far better understand of these things

90.40.text: As I became a teenager, my love of alternative music led me to

97.38.text: and androgony within the music world

101.06.text: and I didn't have present myself in the way society expected

112.30.text: Though, this time I resigned myself to the fact I was male

116.70.text: I realised I could have an impact on those around me by challenging notions of masculinity

123.52.text: And what it is to be male rather than challenging or changing my physical gender

131.22.text: I might have transitioned if I had have confronted these things before

135.16.text: puberty and grew up in more enlightened times but it wasn't something I felt I could have talked to my parents about

141.66.text: I don't believe in the notion of opposite sex

144.96.text: I think we're all more female and male than we let on

149.40.text: And to a considerable degree it's social conditioning

152.56.text: which leads us to present ourselves in a more masculine

157.88.text: To me ideas of mascuinity and feminity are largely social constructs

163.80.text: We are all female in the womb in our earliest stages of developement

168.82.text: I don't know if there are some colors that resonate with people, but maybe I am genderqueer

173.09.text: but one thing I am not very tolerant of is definitions, so

177.64.text: therefore I avoid that one as well as the gender one

186.46.text: (singing) You motherf*ckers need someone to hate

188.94.text: They've got a burden and you’re feeling its weight

191.12.text: ‘Cause you don’t fit into their narrow-mind’s space

193.38.text: You've been kicked down and spat in the face

195.80.text: Do they insult you, do they call you a fag

197.80.text: Use you as a human punching bag

199.80.text:
Lash out at you because they’re scared of 
themselves

202.88.text: It’s always easier to hate someone else
